holdings.reasoning_summary: Limitation already expired when application made; appellant sought to bar future amendments, not assist plaintiff.

holdings.text: Courts would, as a rule, decline to allow amendments if a fresh suit on the amended claim would be barred by limitation but that is a factor for discretion and does not affect the power if required in interests of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent binding; discretion based on justice vs. accrued rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts analogous to Charan Das Privy Council case; no bad faith, relief nature unchanged.

holdings.text: Not feasible nor advisable to encase discretionary power within strait jacket of inflexible formula; quantity of relief not affected by amendments.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects Beaman J's rigid two tests; amendment removed defect without changing relief quantum.

holdings.text: Correct principles enunciated by Batchelor J.: amendments ought to be allowed which satisfy two conditions (a) not working injustice to other side and (b) necessary for determining real questions in controversy.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses Batchelor J over Beaman J; general doctrine from authorities.

holdings.text: Ultimate test remains: can the amendment be allowed without injustice to the other side, or can it not?
holdings.reasoning_summary: Summarizes Batchelor J doctrine; applies to barred claims if compensable.

holdings.text: Amendments do not really introduce a new case or cause of action; appellant not taken by surprise nor meeting new claim post-limitation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's prior application shows awareness; plaint implied title via prior decree; no prejudice.

precedents.citation: L. J. Leach Co. v. Jardine Skinner Co.  1

anchor.surface_text: L. J. Leach Co. v. Jardine Skinner Co.  1  where, in allowing an amendment of the plaint in an appeal before us, we said It is numberdoubt true that companyrts would, as a rule, decline to allow amendments, if a fresh suit on the amended claim would be barred by limitation on the date of the application. But that is a factor to be taken into account in exercise of the discretion as to whether amendment should be ordered, and does number affect the power of the companyrt to order it, if that is required in the interests of justice. These observations were made in a case where damages were, originally claimed on the footing of companyversion of goods.

precedents.case_name: L. J. Leach Co. v. Jardine Skinner Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Amendment of plaint can be allowed even if a fresh suit on amended claim would be barred by limitation; it is a discretionary factor, not affecting the power to amend if justice requires.
precedents.cited_holding: It is not doubt true that courts would, as a rule, decline to allow amendments, if a fresh suit on the amended claim would be barred by limitation on the date of the application. But that is a factor to be taken into account in exercise of the discretion as to whether amendment should be ordered, and does not affect the power of the court to order it, if that is required in the interests of justice.

anchor.surface_text: We accepted as correct the decision in Charan Das v. Amir Khan  2  which laid down that though there was full power to make the amendment, such a power should number, as a rule be exercised where the effect was to take away from a defendant, a legal right which had accrued to him by  1  1957 S.C.R. 438,  2  1920 L.R. 47 I.A. 255. lapse of time yet there were cases where such companysi- derations were outweighed by the special circumstances of the case .

precedents.cited_proposition: Full power exists to amend plaint even if it removes a defendant's accrued right by limitation, but as a rule should not be exercised unless special circumstances outweigh.
precedents.cited_holding: though there was full power to make the amendment, such a power should not, as a rule be exercised where the effect was to take away from a defendant, a legal right which had accrued to him by lapse of time yet there were cases where such considerations were outweighed by the special circumstances of the case.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out in Charan Das case  1 , the power exercised was undoubtedly one within the discretion of the learned Judges. All that can be urged is that the discretion was exercised on a wrong principle. We do number think that it was so exercised in the present case The facts of the present case are very similar to those of the case before their Lordships of the Privy Council.  1  1920 L.R. 47 I.A. 255.

precedents.cited_proposition: The power to allow amendment is discretionary.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellant referred us to the decision in Kisandas Bupchand v. Rachappa Vithoba and placed great reliance on the observations of Beaman J. at P. 655 In my opinion, two simple tests, and two only, need to be applied, in order to ascertain whether a given case is within the principle. First, companyld the party asking to amend obtain the same quantity of relief without the amendment ? If number, then it follows necessarily that the proposed amendment places the other party at a disadvantage,  1  1920 L.R. 47 I.A. 255.  2  1900 I.L.R. 33 Bom. 644.

precedents.cited_proposition: Two tests for amendment: whether same relief obtainable without it (disadvantage if not), and whether disadvantage compensable by costs (deny if not).
precedents.cited_holding: In my opinion, two simple tests, and two only, need to be applied... First, could the party asking to amend obtain the same quantity of relief without the amendment? If not... Second... can the party thus placed at a disadvantage be compensated for it by costs? If not, then the amendment ought not... to be allowed.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the correct principles were enunciated by Batchelor J. in his judgment in the same Case, ViZ., Kisandas Rupchands case 1 , when he said at pp. 649-650 All amendments ought to be allowed which satisfy the two conditions  a  of not working injustice to the other side, and  b  of being necessary for the purpose of determining the real questions in controversy between the parties but I refrain from citing further authorities, as, in my opinion, they all lay down precisely the same doctrine.  1  1900 I.L.R. 33 Bom. 644.

precedents.cited_proposition: Amendments should be allowed if they do not work injustice to the other side (compensable by costs) and are necessary to determine real controversy; refused only if injury not compensable by costs.
precedents.cited_holding: All amendments ought to be allowed which satisfy the two conditions (a) of not working injustice to the other side, and (b) of being necessary for the purpose of determining the real questions in controversy between the parties... amendments should be refused only where the other party cannot be placed in the same position as if the pleading had been originally correct, but the amendment would cause him an injury which could not be compensated in costs.

anchor.surface_text: All that can be urged is that the discretion was exercised on a wrong principle. In the latter, the respondents sued for a declaration of their right of pre- emption over certain land, a form of suit which would number lie having regard to the proviso to s. 42 of the Specific Relief Act  I of 1877 . The trial Judge and the first appellate Court refused to allow the plaint to be amended by claiming possession on pre-emption, since the time had expired for bringing a suit to enforce the right. Upon a second appeal the Court allowed the amendment to be made, there being numberground for suspecting that the plaintiffs had number acted in good faith, and the proposed amendment number altering the nature of the relief sought.
